7. Endpoint Response Time Troubleshooting

  1. Measure Response Times: Use monitoring tools like Application Insights or Postman.
  2. Profiling: Profile the API to find bottlenecks (e.g., slow queries, heavy computations).
  3. Database Optimization: Optimize queries and indexes to reduce DB latency.
  4. Asynchronous Code: Use async/await for non-blocking I/O operations.
  5. Caching: Implement caching for frequently accessed data.
  6. CDN Usage: Use CDNs for static content.
  7. Load Balancing: Distribute traffic to reduce server load.
  8. Scalability: Ensure proper scaling of resources.

8. How Does the Lazy Loading Approach Work?

Lazy Loading is a design pattern that delays the loading of an object or data until it’s needed, improving performance by avoiding unnecessary operations.

In C#, use Lazy<T> for lazy initialization:

Lazy<HeavyObject> lazyObject = new(() => new HeavyObject());

Lazy loading in EF Core:

services.AddDbContext<AppDbContext>(options => options.UseLazyLoadingProxies());

9. What Is the Difference Between Async Calls and Parallel Calls?

Feature

Async Calls

Parallel Calls

Definition

Asynchronous execution, non-blocking

Concurrent execution using multiple threads

Concurrency

Often single-threaded (non-blocking I/O)

Multi-threaded

Use Case

I/O-bound tasks

CPU-bound tasks

Example of Async Call:

await Task.Delay(1000);

Example of Parallel Call:

Parallel.For(0, 10, i => {

    Console.WriteLine(i);

});

10. How Do You Create a LINQ Extension Method?

An extension method is a static method defined in a static class and acts as if it were part of an existing type.

Example of LINQ Extension Method:

public static class MyExtensions {

    public static IEnumerable<T> Filter<T>(this IEnumerable<T> source, Func<T, bool> predicate) {

        foreach (var item in source) {

            if (predicate(item)) yield return item;

        }

    }

}

Usage:

var numbers = new[] { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 };

var evenNumbers = numbers.Filter(n => n % 2 == 0);

Summary

These concepts and techniques are foundational for working with C# and .NET. They enhance code maintainability, optimize performance, and ensure robustness in multi-threaded environments and distributed systems.

 

Q: Integrate Okta authorization in blazor app

 

Integrating Okta Authorization in a Blazor application involves configuring Okta as an identity provider and using its OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocols for user authentication and authorization. Here's how to do it step-by-step:

1. Set Up an Application in Okta

  1. Log in to Okta:
    • Go to Okta Developer Console.
    • Create an account if you don’t have one.
  2. Create an Application:
    • Navigate to Applications > Applications.
    • Click Create App Integration.
    • Select OIDC - OpenID Connect and Web Application.
    • Click Next.
  3. Configure the Application:
    • Sign-in redirect URI: Set to your application's base URL + /authentication/login-callback.
      Example for local development:
      https://localhost:5001/authentication/login-callback
    • Sign-out redirect URI: Set to your application's base URL.
      Example: https://localhost:5001.
    • Assign appropriate users or groups to the app.
  4. Save the Configuration:
    • Note the Client ID, Client Secret, and Issuer URL (e.g., https://your-okta-domain.okta.com/oauth2/default).

2. Configure the Blazor Application

Install Required NuGet Packages

Add the following NuGet packages to your Blazor application:

dotnet add package Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect

dotnet add package Microsoft.Identity.Web

dotnet add package Microsoft.Identity.Web.UI

Update appsettings.json

Add Okta configuration details:

{

  "Okta": {

    "Authority": "https://your-okta-domain.okta.com/oauth2/default",

    "ClientId": "YOUR_CLIENT_ID",

    "ClientSecret": "YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET",

    "ResponseType": "code"

  }

}

Replace your-okta-domain with your Okta domain and YOUR_CLIENT_ID/YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET with your app's credentials.

Configure Authentication in Program.cs

Update Program.cs to add authentication and authorization:

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

 

// Add services

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(options =>

{

    options.DefaultScheme = "Cookies";

    options.DefaultChallengeScheme = "oidc";

})

.AddCookie("Cookies")

.AddOpenIdConnect("oidc", options =>

{

    options.Authority = builder.Configuration["Okta:Authority"];

    options.ClientId = builder.Configuration["Okta:ClientId"];

    options.ClientSecret = builder.Configuration["Okta:ClientSecret"];

    options.ResponseType = builder.Configuration["Okta:ResponseType"];

    options.SaveTokens = true; // Save tokens in cookies for later use

    options.Scope.Add("openid");

    options.Scope.Add("profile");

    options.Scope.Add("email");

});

 

builder.Services.AddAuthorizationCore();

 

var app = builder.Build();

 

app.UseAuthentication();

app.UseAuthorization();

 

app.MapBlazorHub();

app.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");

 

app.Run();

Add Login and Logout Buttons

In your Blazor components (e.g., MainLayout.razor), add login/logout links:

@inject NavigationManager NavigationManager

@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication

 

<div>

    @if (!context.User.Identity.IsAuthenticated)

    {

        <button @onclick="Login">Login</button>

    }

    else

    {

        <button @onclick="Logout">Logout</button>

        <p>Welcome, @context.User.Identity.Name</p>

    }

</div>

 

@code {

    async Task Login()

    {

        NavigationManager.NavigateTo("authentication/login");

    }

 

    async Task Logout()

    {

        NavigationManager.NavigateTo("authentication/logout");

    }

}

3. Protect Pages with Authorization

Decorate Blazor pages or components with the [Authorize] attribute to restrict access to authenticated users.

Example:

@page "/secure"

@attribute [Authorize]

 

<h3>Secure Page</h3>

 

<p>This page is only accessible to authenticated users.</p>

4. Test the Integration

  1. Run your Blazor app.
  2. Navigate to a protected page.
  3. When prompted, log in via Okta.
  4. After successful authentication, you should be redirected back to your app.

Optional Enhancements

  1. Role-Based Authorization:
    • Add roles or groups in Okta and assign them to users.
    • Use options.Scope.Add("groups"); in the OpenID Connect configuration.
    • Check roles in Blazor using:
    • @if (context.User.IsInRole("Admin")) {
    •     <p>Admin Content</p>
    • }
  2. API Authorization:
    • Use access tokens (options.SaveTokens = true) to call secured APIs.
    • Add Authorization headers in HTTP requests using Bearer <access_token>.

Summary

Integrating Okta into a Blazor app allows seamless authentication and authorization using OAuth 2.0 and OIDC. With Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect, you can easily handle login, logout, token management, and role-based access control. Use Okta's dashboard to manage users, roles, and app configurations.

Q: Is Blazor default package manage the access_token

 

Ans:

Yes, Blazor provides built-in support for managing the access token in Blazor applications, but the behavior varies depending on whether you are using Blazor Server or Blazor WebAssembly. Here’s how it works:

1. Blazor Server

Blazor Server applications do not inherently handle access tokens for client-side use because all interactions occur on the server. However, you can:

  • Use the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication package to retrieve and manage access tokens.
  • Access tokens are typically stored in server-side session data or cookies, not exposed directly to the client.

Example of Token Management in Blazor Server

Configure authentication middleware in Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(options =>

    {

        builder.Configuration.Bind("AzureAd", options);

        options.SaveTokens = true; // Saves tokens for access

    });

Retrieve the access_token in a Razor component or page:

@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication

@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect

 

@code {

    private async Task<string> GetAccessTokenAsync()

    {

        var authResult = await HttpContext.GetTokenAsync("access_token");

        return authResult ?? "No access token available.";

    }

}

2. Blazor WebAssembly

Blazor WebAssembly supports managing access tokens directly using the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication package. This package includes services and helpers to handle tokens, store them securely, and pass them in HTTP requests.

Example of Token Management in Blazor WebAssembly

Install Required NuGet Packages

dotnet add package Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication

Configure Token Retrieval

In Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("API", client => client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com"))

    .AddHttpMessageHandler<BaseAddressAuthorizationMessageHandler>();

 

builder.Services.AddOidcAuthentication(options =>

{

    builder.Configuration.Bind("Okta", options.ProviderOptions);

    options.ProviderOptions.DefaultScopes.Add("openid");

    options.ProviderOptions.DefaultScopes.Add("profile");

    options.ProviderOptions.DefaultScopes.Add("email");

});

Using the Access Token in API Calls

Blazor WebAssembly automatically attaches the access_token to HTTP requests if you use BaseAddressAuthorizationMessageHandler.

Example API call in a component:

@inject HttpClient HttpClient

 

@code {

    private async Task FetchData()

    {

        var data = await HttpClient.GetAsync("protected-resource");

    }

}

Default Behavior for Tokens

  1. Storage:
    • In Blazor WebAssembly, tokens are stored in memory by default to avoid exposing them in insecure places like local storage or session storage.
  2. Token Lifetime Management:
    • Tokens typically expire after a certain period. Blazor doesn’t automatically refresh tokens unless configured.
    • You can handle token expiration using the IAccessTokenProvider service to retrieve new tokens.

Example:

@inject IAccessTokenProvider TokenProvider

 

@code {

    private async Task<string> GetAccessTokenAsync()

    {

        var result = await TokenProvider.RequestAccessToken();

        if (result.TryGetToken(out var token))

        {

            return token.Value;

        }

        return "No token available.";

    }

}

  1. Scopes:
    • Blazor manages scopes during authentication setup. Ensure you add required scopes in the DefaultScopes or explicitly request them during login.

Summary

  • Blazor Server: Manages tokens server-side and does not expose them to the client.
  • Blazor WebAssembly: Has built-in token management through Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication, stores tokens securely, and integrates them with HTTP requests.

If additional customization is required, Blazor provides flexibility to fetch, refresh, and securely store tokens manually.

 

Q: Is blazor takes care of session time limit increase using refresh token

 

Ans:

Blazor itself does not automatically handle refresh tokens or extend session time limits by refreshing access tokens out of the box. However, Blazor does provide tools and mechanisms to help you implement refresh token handling manually or via libraries.

Understanding Refresh Tokens in Blazor

  • Access Token: Short-lived, used to authenticate API requests.
  • Refresh Token: Long-lived, used to obtain a new access token when the current one expires.

To handle session timeouts and token expiration effectively in Blazor, you need to implement refresh token management yourself or use a library that supports it.

Blazor Server

In Blazor Server, tokens are typically stored on the server (e.g., in session state, cookies, or a secure database). You can implement refresh token handling using middleware or background services.

Example:

  1. Enable Token Saving: Configure Microsoft.Identity.Web to save tokens:
  2. builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
  3.     .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(options =>
  4.     {
  5.         builder.Configuration.Bind("AzureAd", options);
  6.         options.SaveTokens = true;
  7.         options.TokenValidationParameters.ClockSkew = TimeSpan.Zero; // Minimize token timing issues
  8.     });
  9. Refresh Tokens Manually: Use the OpenID Connect endpoint to exchange the refresh token for a new access token before it expires.

Blazor WebAssembly

In Blazor WebAssembly, managing refresh tokens is more involved because the app runs on the client side. Here’s how to manage token expiration and refresh:

Steps to Handle Refresh Tokens in Blazor WebAssembly

  1. Access Token Expiration Monitoring: Use the IAccessTokenProvider service to monitor access token expiration.

Example:

@inject IAccessTokenProvider TokenProvider

 

@code {

    private async Task<string> EnsureValidAccessToken()

    {

        var result = await TokenProvider.RequestAccessToken(new AccessTokenRequestOptions

        {

            Scopes = new[] { "api_scope" }

        });

 

        if (result.TryGetToken(out var token))

        {

            return token.Value;

        }

        return null; // Token refresh failed or user not authenticated

    }

}

  1. Refresh Token via HTTP Interceptor: Use an HttpClient handler to intercept failed requests (e.g., with 401 Unauthorized) and attempt token refresh.

Example:

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("API", client => client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com"))

    .AddHttpMessageHandler<BaseAddressAuthorizationMessageHandler>();

  1. Store Refresh Tokens Securely: Since refresh tokens are sensitive, store them securely in-memory or use a secure storage mechanism (e.g., browser cookies with the HttpOnly flag).
  2. Fetch New Access Tokens: Make an HTTP call to the token endpoint of your Identity Provider (e.g., Okta, Azure AD B2C) using the refresh token:
  3. private async Task<string> RefreshAccessTokenAsync(string refreshToken)
  4. {
  5.     var httpClient = new HttpClient();
  6.     var response = await httpClient.PostAsync("https://identity-provider.com/oauth/token",
  7.         new FormUrlEncodedContent(new Dictionary<string, string>
  8.            {
  9.                { "grant_type", "refresh_token" },
  10.                { "client_id", "your-client-id" },
  11.                { "refresh_token", refreshToken }
  12.            }));
  13.     
  14.        if (response.IsSuccessStatusCode)
  15.        {
  16.            var responseContent = await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync();
  17.            var tokenResponse = JsonSerializer.Deserialize<TokenResponse>(responseContent);
  18.            return tokenResponse?.AccessToken;
  19.        }
  20.     
  21.        return null;
  22.    }
  23.     
  24.    private class TokenResponse
  25.    {
  26.        [JsonPropertyName("access_token")]
  27.        public string AccessToken { get; set; }
  28.     
  29.        [JsonPropertyName("expires_in")]
  30.        public int ExpiresIn { get; set; }
  31.     
  32.        [JsonPropertyName("refresh_token")]
  33.        public string RefreshToken { get; set; }
  34.    }
  35. Periodic Token Refresh: Set up a timer or background task to refresh the token before it expires:
  36.    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()
  37.    {
  38.        await RefreshAccessTokenAsync();
  39.        var timer = new Timer(async _ => await RefreshAccessTokenAsync(), null, TimeSpan.Zero, TimeSpan.FromMinutes(5));
  40.    }

Considerations for Refresh Tokens

  1. Secure Storage:
    • In Blazor WebAssembly, avoid storing refresh tokens in local storage or session storage due to XSS risks.
    • Use Secure Cookies or pass the refresh token to a backend service for management.
  2. Token Lifetime:
    • Work with your Identity Provider to configure reasonable expiration times for access and refresh tokens.
    • Use sliding expiration for long-running sessions.
  3. Silent Token Refresh:
    • Use the iframe technique or the openid protocol's prompt=none flow to refresh tokens without user interaction.
  4. Fallback for Token Expiration:
    • If the refresh token fails, redirect the user to re-authenticate.

Summary

  • Blazor does not manage refresh tokens out of the box, but it provides tools (IAccessTokenProvider, HttpClient, OpenIdConnect) to implement token refresh logic.
  • In Blazor Server, refresh tokens are typically managed server-side using middleware or background services.
  • In Blazor WebAssembly, you need to handle refresh tokens securely on the client and periodically request new access tokens.

By implementing token management properly, you can extend session lifetimes securely and provide a seamless user experience.

Q: blazor project structure for components like layout, pages, common or reusable components

 

Ans:

Creating a well-structured Blazor project helps in organizing your components, layouts, and reusable code, making the project easier to maintain and scale. Here’s a recommended folder structure and explanation for each section:

Recommended Blazor Project Structure

1. Project Root

  • Pages/: Contains all the application-specific pages.
  • Shared/: Contains reusable components like layouts, navigation menus, and common UI elements.
  • Components/: Contains modular, reusable Blazor components.
  • wwwroot/: Contains static assets (CSS, JavaScript, images, etc.).
  • Services/: Contains service classes (e.g., APIs, data access, business logic).
  • Models/: Contains data models or DTOs used throughout the application.
  • Data/: Contains classes related to data handling, like context files or seeding.
  • State/: Manages application-wide state management (optional, for larger apps).
  • Extensions/: Contains helper methods or extension methods.
  • Resources/: Contains localization or resource files (if required).
  • App.razor: The root component of the application.
  • MainLayout.razor: The default layout for the application.

2. Folder Breakdown

Pages/

Holds the application’s routeable pages. Each .razor file typically maps to a specific route.

Structure:

Pages/

  Home.razor

  About.razor

  Contact.razor

  Login.razor

  Error.razor

Example: Home.razor

@page "/"

 

<h1>Welcome to the Home Page</h1>

<p>This is the homepage of the application.</p>

Shared/

Contains layout files, navigation menus, footers, or any other UI components shared across pages.

Structure:

Shared/

  MainLayout.razor

  NavMenu.razor

  Footer.razor

  Sidebar.razor

Example: MainLayout.razor

@inherits LayoutComponentBase

 

<div class="main-layout">

    <NavMenu />

    <div class="content">

        @Body

    </div>

    <Footer />

</div>

Components/

Holds reusable, modular components that can be used across multiple pages or other components. Think of these as building blocks.

Structure:

Components/

  Button.razor

  Modal.razor

  DataTable.razor

  Chart.razor

Example: Button.razor

<button @onclick="OnClick" class="btn btn-primary">

    @Label

</button>

 

@code {

    [Parameter] public string Label { get; set; }

    [Parameter] public EventCallback OnClick { get; set; }

}

wwwroot/

Contains static assets like CSS, JavaScript, and images.

Structure:

wwwroot/

  css/

    app.css

  js/

    app.js

  images/

    logo.png

Example: app.css

body {

    font-family: Arial, sans-serif;

}

Services/

Contains services for handling application logic, API calls, or third-party integrations.

Structure:

Services/

  AuthenticationService.cs

  ApiService.cs

  UserService.cs

Example: ApiService.cs

public class ApiService

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

 

    public ApiService(HttpClient httpClient)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

    }

 

    public async Task<List<T>> GetDataAsync<T>(string endpoint)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(endpoint);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<List<T>>();

    }

}

Models/

Contains models representing your application’s data structures.

Structure:

Models/

  User.cs

  Product.cs

  Order.cs

Example: User.cs

public class User

{

    public int Id { get; set; }

    public string Name { get; set; }

    public string Email { get; set; }

}

State/

Manages shared application state, often used for larger applications requiring global state management.

Structure:

State/

  AppState.cs

  UserState.cs

Example: AppState.cs

public class AppState

{

    public string Theme { get; set; } = "Light";

 

    public event Action? StateChanged;

 

    public void SetTheme(string theme)

    {

        Theme = theme;

        StateChanged?.Invoke();

    }

}

Extensions/

Holds reusable helper or extension methods.

Structure:

Extensions/

  HttpClientExtensions.cs

  StringExtensions.cs

Example: HttpClientExtensions.cs

public static class HttpClientExtensions

{

    public static async Task<T> ReadAsJsonAsync<T>(this HttpContent content)

    {

        return await content.ReadFromJsonAsync<T>();

    }

}

Resources/

Holds localization resources for multi-language support.

Structure:

Resources/

  en-US.resx

  fr-FR.resx

Global Files

  • App.razor: Root component where routing and authentication are set up.
  • _Imports.razor: Contains common using directives for Razor components.

Example: App.razor

<CascadingAuthenticationState>

    <Router AppAssembly="@typeof(Program).Assembly">

        <Found Context="routeData">

            <RouteView RouteData="@routeData" DefaultLayout="@typeof(MainLayout)" />

            <FocusOnNavigate RouteData="@routeData" Selector="h1" />

        </Found>

        <NotFound>

            <LayoutView Layout="@typeof(MainLayout)">

                <p>Page not found!</p>

            </LayoutView>

        </NotFound>

    </Router>

</CascadingAuthenticationState>

Benefits of This Structure

  1. Modularity: Separation of concerns for easier debugging and testing.
  2. Scalability: Clear boundaries make the app easier to extend.
  3. Reusability: Centralized components and services reduce duplication.
  4. Maintainability: Easier to onboard new developers or revisit the code after time.

This structure serves as a guideline and can be adjusted based on your project’s specific requirements.

 

Q: Blazor app services can implement using interface and create dynamic base class to call the API project based on api path, Http method

 

Ans:

Yes, you can create a dynamic base service class in a Blazor application to handle API calls using an interface-driven approach. This allows for clean, reusable, and extensible code while dynamically handling different API paths and HTTP methods.

Here’s how you can implement this pattern:

Steps to Implement

1. Define a Service Interface

Create an interface that defines the operations for your API services. This promotes consistency and makes the code easier to mock and test.

Example:

public interface IApiService

{

    Task<TResponse> GetAsync<TResponse>(string apiPath);

    Task<TResponse> PostAsync<TRequest, TResponse>(string apiPath, TRequest data);

    Task<TResponse> PutAsync<TRequest, TResponse>(string apiPath, TRequest data);

    Task DeleteAsync(string apiPath);

}

2. Create a Base Service Class

This class implements the interface and handles API requests dynamically based on the API path and HTTP method. It uses HttpClient for communication.

Example:

public class BaseApiService : IApiService

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

 

    public BaseApiService(HttpClient httpClient)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

    }

 

    public async Task<TResponse> GetAsync<TResponse>(string apiPath)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(apiPath);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<TResponse>();

    }

 

    public async Task<TResponse> PostAsync<TRequest, TResponse>(string apiPath, TRequest data)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.PostAsJsonAsync(apiPath, data);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<TResponse>();

    }

 

    public async Task<TResponse> PutAsync<TRequest, TResponse>(string apiPath, TRequest data)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.PutAsJsonAsync(apiPath, data);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<TResponse>();

    }

 

    public async Task DeleteAsync(string apiPath)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.DeleteAsync(apiPath);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

    }

}

3. Create Specialized API Services

You can create specialized service classes that inherit from the base class. These classes focus on specific API areas, providing clear separation of concerns.

Example:

public interface IUserService

{

    Task<User> GetUserByIdAsync(int id);

    Task<List<User>> GetAllUsersAsync();

    Task CreateUserAsync(User user);

}

 

public class UserService : BaseApiService, IUserService

{

    public UserService(HttpClient httpClient) : base(httpClient) { }

 

    public async Task<User> GetUserByIdAsync(int id)

    {

        return await GetAsync<User>($"api/users/{id}");

    }

 

    public async Task<List<User>> GetAllUsersAsync()

    {

        return await GetAsync<List<User>>("api/users");

    }

 

    public async Task CreateUserAsync(User user)

    {

        await PostAsync<User, object>("api/users", user);

    }

}

4. Dependency Injection in Blazor

Register your services in Program.cs or Startup.cs:

builder.Services.AddHttpClient<BaseApiService>(client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://your-api-url.com");

});

 

builder.Services.AddScoped<IUserService, UserService>();

5. Use the Service in a Component

Example of consuming the UserService in a Blazor component:

@inject IUserService UserService

 

<h3>User List</h3>

 

@if (users == null)

{

    <p>Loading...</p>

}

else

{

    <ul>

        @foreach (var user in users)

        {

            <li>@user.Name</li>

        }

    </ul>

}

 

@code {

    private List<User>? users;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        users = await UserService.GetAllUsersAsync();

    }

}

Dynamic API Path Handling

If you need even more flexibility to define API paths dynamically, you can add parameters or templates to the BaseApiService.

Example:

public async Task<TResponse> GetDynamicAsync<TResponse>(string apiPath, Dictionary<string, string> queryParams)

{

    var query = string.Join("&", queryParams.Select(kvp => $"{kvp.Key}={Uri.EscapeDataString(kvp.Value)}"));

    var fullPath = $"{apiPath}?{query}";

 

    var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(fullPath);

    response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

    return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<TResponse>();

}

Usage:

var queryParams = new Dictionary<string, string>

{

    { "filter", "active" },

    { "sortBy", "name" }

};

var result = await UserService.GetDynamicAsync<List<User>>("api/users", queryParams);

Benefits of This Approach

  1. Reusable Code: The base class centralizes the logic for API calls.
  2. Flexibility: Supports dynamic API paths and HTTP methods.
  3. Maintainability: Specialized services provide clear separation of responsibilities.
  4. Extensibility: Adding new endpoints or API areas is straightforward.
  5. Testability: Interfaces make it easy to mock and test services.

This structure is highly effective for maintaining clean and scalable Blazor applications.

 

Q: best way to maintain api paths, not hard coded, more modular and dynamic

 

Ans:

To maintain API paths in a modular, dynamic, and non-hardcoded way, you can create a centralized system to manage these paths. This ensures scalability, maintainability, and the ability to adapt paths dynamically based on environments or configurations.

Best Practices for Managing API Paths

1. Use a Centralized Configuration Class

Create a class to store and manage all your API paths. You can organize endpoints hierarchically for better clarity.

Example:

public static class ApiRoutes

{

    public static class Users

    {

        public const string GetAll = "api/users";

        public const string GetById = "api/users/{id}";

        public const string Create = "api/users";

        public const string Update = "api/users/{id}";

        public const string Delete = "api/users/{id}";

    }

 

    public static class Products

    {

        public const string GetAll = "api/products";

        public const string GetById = "api/products/{id}";

    }

}

Usage:

var getUsersEndpoint = ApiRoutes.Users.GetAll;

var getProductByIdEndpoint = ApiRoutes.Products.GetById.Replace("{id}", productId.ToString());

2. Environment-Based Configuration

To handle different API base URLs (e.g., development, staging, production), use appsettings.json or environment-specific configurations.

appsettings.json:

{

  "ApiSettings": {

    "BaseUrl": "https://api.yourdomain.com",

    "Endpoints": {

      "Users": "api/users",

      "Products": "api/products"

    }

  }

}

Read these values in your service:

public class ApiSettings

{

    public string BaseUrl { get; set; }

    public Dictionary<string, string> Endpoints { get; set; }

}

Register the settings in Program.cs:

builder.Services.Configure<ApiSettings>(builder.Configuration.GetSection("ApiSettings"));

Inject IOptions<ApiSettings> in your service:

public class UserService

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

    private readonly ApiSettings _apiSettings;

 

    public UserService(HttpClient httpClient, IOptions<ApiSettings> apiSettings)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

        _apiSettings = apiSettings.Value;

    }

 

    public async Task<List<User>> GetAllUsersAsync()

    {

        var endpoint = $"{_apiSettings.BaseUrl}/{_apiSettings.Endpoints["Users"]}";

        var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(endpoint);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadFromJsonAsync<List<User>>();

    }

}

3. Use Typed HTTP Clients with Strongly-Typed Endpoints

Create a typed HttpClient for each service. This promotes modularity and simplifies endpoint management.

Typed Client Configuration:

public class UserApiClient

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

 

    public UserApiClient(HttpClient httpClient)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

    }

 

    public Task<List<User>> GetAllUsersAsync() =>

        _httpClient.GetFromJsonAsync<List<User>>("api/users");

 

    public Task<User> GetUserByIdAsync(int id) =>

        _httpClient.GetFromJsonAsync<User>($"api/users/{id}");

}

Register in Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddHttpClient<UserApiClient>(client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.yourdomain.com");

});

Inject and use:

@inject UserApiClient UserApiClient

 

@code {

    private List<User>? users;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        users = await UserApiClient.GetAllUsersAsync();

    }

}

4. Dynamic Path Generation with Helper Methods

Use helper methods to build dynamic API paths, especially for routes with parameters.

Example:

public static class ApiPathHelper

{

    public static string GetPath(string basePath, params (string key, string value)[] parameters)

    {

        foreach (var param in parameters)

        {

            basePath = basePath.Replace($"{{{param.key}}}", param.value);

        }

        return basePath;

    }

}

Usage:

string endpoint = ApiPathHelper.GetPath(ApiRoutes.Users.GetById, ("id", "123"));

5. Use Custom Attributes for API Endpoints

For a more declarative approach, use attributes to define API paths on models or controllers.

Example:

[ApiRoute("api/users")]

public class UserService

{

    [ApiEndpoint("GET", "/{id}")]

    public string GetUserByIdEndpoint { get; set; }

}

Helper to fetch endpoints dynamically:

public static class ApiRouteHelper

{

    public static string GetRoute<T>(Expression<Func<T, object>> expression)

    {

        var member = (MemberExpression)expression.Body;

        var attribute = member.Member.GetCustomAttribute<ApiEndpointAttribute>();

        return attribute?.Path ?? string.Empty;

    }

}

6. Combine Routes and HTTP Methods in Enums

Using enums for API routes and HTTP methods can reduce hardcoding further.

Example:

public enum ApiEndpoints

{

    [Route("api/users", HttpMethod.Get)]

    GetAllUsers,

 

    [Route("api/users/{id}", HttpMethod.Get)]

    GetUserById

}

Custom attribute and helper:

[AttributeUsage(AttributeTargets.Field)]

public class RouteAttribute : Attribute

{

    public string Path { get; }

    public HttpMethod Method { get; }

 

    public RouteAttribute(string path, HttpMethod method)

    {

        Path = path;

        Method = method;

    }

}

 

public static class ApiEndpointHelper

{

    public static (string Path, HttpMethod Method) GetRoute(ApiEndpoints endpoint)

    {

        var fieldInfo = endpoint.GetType().GetField(endpoint.ToString());

        var attribute = fieldInfo?.GetCustomAttribute<RouteAttribute>();

        return (attribute?.Path ?? string.Empty, attribute?.Method ?? HttpMethod.Get);

    }

}

Summary

  • For Static API Paths: Use a centralized ApiRoutes class.
  • For Dynamic API Paths: Use helper methods or centralized configuration.
  • For Environment Flexibility: Use appsettings.json or environment-based configs.
  • For Strongly-Typed Endpoints: Leverage typed HTTP clients or attributes.
  • For Declarative APIs: Use custom attributes to define routes and helpers for retrieval.

By following these practices, you make API path management modular, scalable, and easy to maintain.

 

Q: In Blazor app, implement authentication using Microsoft Azure AD using ClientId, authority

 

Ans:

Implementing authentication in a Blazor app using Microsoft Azure AD involves configuring the app to use Azure AD for identity and access management. Here's a step-by-step guide for integrating Azure AD authentication into a Blazor WebAssembly app:

Steps to Implement Azure AD Authentication

1. Register the Application in Azure AD

  1. Login to Azure Portal: Navigate to Azure Active Directory.
  2. Register the Application:
    • Go to App registrations > New registration.
    • Enter a Name for the app (e.g., BlazorApp).
    • For Supported account types, select the appropriate option based on your organization (e.g., Accounts in this organizational directory only).
    • Set Redirect URI:
      • Select platform Web.
      • Add https://localhost:5001/authentication/login-callback (adjust for your app's base URL).
    • Click Register.
  3. Note the Application (Client) ID and the Directory (Tenant) ID.
  4. Configure API Permissions:
    • Go to API Permissions.
    • Click Add a permission > Microsoft Graph > Delegated permissions.
    • Select permissions like openid, profile, and email (if needed).
    • Grant admin consent if required.

2. Install Required NuGet Packages

Add the following NuGet packages to your Blazor WebAssembly project:

dotnet add package Microsoft.Authentication.WebAssembly.Msal

dotnet add package Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication

3. Configure Authentication in Program.cs

Modify the Program.cs file to configure the HttpClient and the authentication provider.

using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication;

using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Hosting;

 

var builder = WebAssemblyHostBuilder.CreateDefault(args);

 

// Configure HTTP Client

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("BlazorApp.ServerAPI", client =>

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri(builder.HostEnvironment.BaseAddress))

    .AddHttpMessageHandler<BaseAddressAuthorizationMessageHandler>();

 

// Add Azure AD Authentication

builder.Services.AddMsalAuthentication(options =>

{

    builder.Configuration.Bind("AzureAd", options.ProviderOptions.Authentication);

    options.ProviderOptions.DefaultAccessTokenScopes.Add("api://<YOUR-API-CLIENT-ID>/access_as_user");

});

 

builder.RootComponents.Add<App>("#app");

 

await builder.Build().RunAsync();

Replace <YOUR-API-CLIENT-ID> with the Application ID of the Azure AD app.

4. Configure wwwroot/appsettings.json

Add the Azure AD configuration in wwwroot/appsettings.json:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/<TENANT-ID>",

    "ClientId": "<CLIENT-ID>",

    "ValidateAuthority": true

  }

}

Replace <TENANT-ID> and <CLIENT-ID> with your Azure AD Directory (Tenant) ID and Application (Client) ID, respectively.

5. Protect Pages and API Calls

Protect Pages with [Authorize]

Use the [Authorize] attribute in App.razor to enforce authentication for specific routes.

<CascadingAuthenticationState>

    <Router AppAssembly="@typeof(App).Assembly">

        <Found Context="routeData">

            <AuthorizeRouteView RouteData="@routeData" DefaultLayout="@typeof(MainLayout)" />

        </Found>

        <NotFound>

            <LayoutView Layout="@typeof(MainLayout)">

                <p>Sorry, there's nothing at this address.</p>

            </LayoutView>

        </NotFound>

    </Router>

</CascadingAuthenticationState>

6. Create a Login and Logout UI

Add login and logout buttons in your navigation or layout:

<AuthorizeView>

    <Authorized>

        <a href="authentication/logout">Logout</a>

    </Authorized>

    <NotAuthorized>

        <a href="authentication/login">Login</a>

    </NotAuthorized>

</AuthorizeView>

7. Call Secure APIs

Inject the HttpClient and use it to make authenticated API calls. The BaseAddressAuthorizationMessageHandler automatically attaches the access token.

Example:

@inject HttpClient HttpClient

 

<h3>Secure Data</h3>

 

@if (data == null)

{

    <p>Loading...</p>

}

else

{

    <p>Data: @data</p>

}

 

@code {

    private string? data;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        data = await HttpClient.GetStringAsync("api/secure-data");

    }

}

8. Enable CORS in the API (if applicable)

If your Blazor app calls a separate API, ensure the API allows cross-origin requests. Update the API project's Startup.cs or equivalent:

public void Configure(IApplicationBuilder app, IWebHostEnvironment env)

{

    app.UseCors(policy => policy

        .AllowAnyOrigin()

        .AllowAnyMethod()

        .AllowAnyHeader());

 

    app.UseAuthentication();

    app.UseAuthorization();

}

9. Run and Test the Application

  1. Start the Blazor WebAssembly app.
  2. Navigate to a protected page.
  3. The app should redirect to Azure AD for login.
  4. After successful login, the app should return to the protected page.

Optional Enhancements

  • Use Graph API: To fetch additional user profile information, add Microsoft.Graph NuGet package and call Graph endpoints.
  • Token Storage: Tokens are managed automatically in Blazor WebAssembly using MsalAuthentication.
  • Custom Scopes: Define custom scopes in Azure AD and request them via options.ProviderOptions.DefaultAccessTokenScopes.

This approach ensures seamless integration with Azure AD for authentication in a Blazor WebAssembly app.

 

 

Q: integrating Azure AD authentication into a Blazor interactive server app

 

Ans:

Integrating Azure AD authentication into a Blazor Server app involves setting up Azure AD to authenticate users and configuring the Blazor app to use Azure AD. Here's a step-by-step guide:

  2. Click New registration and provide:

  1. Go to Certificates & secrets > New client secret.
  2. Add a description and expiration period, then save.
  3. Copy the secret value for later use.

In your Blazor Server app, install the necessary packages for Azure AD authentication:

This setup ensures secure authentication with Azure AD in your Blazor Server app.

 

Q: what is downstream api in Identity

 

Ans:

A downstream API in the context of identity and authentication refers to an external API or service that your application calls on behalf of an authenticated user. This typically happens in scenarios where your application needs to interact with other protected resources, such as APIs hosted by your organization, third-party services, or Microsoft APIs like Microsoft Graph.

The "downstream" terminology reflects the flow of communication from your application (the client) to an API or service (the downstream target).

How It Works

  1. Authentication:
    • The user logs into your application using an identity provider (e.g., Azure AD, Auth0).
    • The identity provider issues an access token for the user.
  2. Token Propagation:
    • Your application uses the access token to authenticate requests to the downstream API.
    • This token acts as proof that the user is authorized to access the requested resource.
  3. Downstream API Authorization:
    • The downstream API validates the token.
    • If valid, the API processes the request and sends a response back to your application.

Example Use Case

Imagine a Blazor app that:

  • Authenticates users with Azure AD.
  • Calls a custom Web API to fetch user-specific data.

Steps in This Scenario:

  1. Authentication:
    • The Blazor app authenticates the user with Azure AD.
    • Azure AD issues an access token with the required scopes for the Web API.
  2. Access Token Usage:
    • The Blazor app includes the access token in the Authorization header of requests to the Web API.

Example:

GET /api/resource HTTP/1.1

Host: api.example.com

Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsIn...

  1. Downstream API:
    • The Web API validates the token using Azure AD's public keys (via OpenID Connect metadata).
    • If the token is valid, the API processes the request and returns the response.

Common Downstream API Scenarios

  1. Microsoft Graph API:
    • A web application fetches user details, emails, or calendar events from Microsoft Graph.
  2. Custom APIs:
    • Internal APIs are secured with Azure AD. Your application needs tokens to access them.
  3. Third-Party APIs:
    • APIs like Stripe, GitHub, or Google APIs require OAuth 2.0 tokens for access.

Key Concepts in Downstream API Authentication

  1. Scopes:
    • Tokens must include the appropriate scopes to access downstream APIs.
    • For example, calling Microsoft Graph to read a user's profile requires the User.Read scope.
  2. Audience (aud):
    • Tokens are issued for specific audiences (e.g., an API's Application ID URI).
    • The downstream API checks the token's aud claim to ensure it was issued for the API.
  3. Delegated vs. Application Permissions:
    • Delegated Permissions: The token is tied to a user and their permissions.
    • Application Permissions: The token represents the app itself, independent of a user.
  4. Token Acquisition:
    • Use libraries like Microsoft.Identity.Web (for server apps) or MSAL.js/MSAL.NET (for client apps) to acquire and manage tokens for downstream APIs.

In Blazor with Azure AD

When implementing downstream API calls in a Blazor app with Azure AD, you typically:

  1. Authenticate the user using Azure AD.
  2. Acquire an access token for the downstream API using the Microsoft.Identity.Web or MSAL libraries.
  3. Include the token in the Authorization header of HTTP requests.

Example Code in Blazor Server:

@inject IAccessTokenProvider TokenProvider

@inject HttpClient HttpClient

 

@code {

    private async Task CallApiAsync()

    {

        var result = await TokenProvider.RequestAccessToken();

        if (result.TryGetToken(out var token))

        {

            HttpClient.DefaultRequestHeaders.Authorization = new AuthenticationHeaderValue("Bearer", token.Value);

            var response = await HttpClient.GetAsync("https://api.example.com/resource");

            // Process response

        }

    }

}

This approach ensures secure interaction with downstream APIs, leveraging Azure AD's identity and token management capabilities.

 

Q: implement Azure AD with Downstream API in Blazor interactive server app and how to apply authorization to pages

 

Ans:

To implement Azure AD authentication with a downstream API in a Blazor Server app and enforce page-level authorization, follow these steps:

1. Set Up Azure AD

1.1 Register the App for Blazor Server

  1. Navigate to Azure AD > App registrations > New registration:
    • Name: BlazorServerApp.
    • Supported account types: Choose the option based on your scenario.
    • Redirect URI: Add https://localhost:5001/signin-oidc (or your app’s URL for production).
  2. Save the Application (Client) ID and Directory (Tenant) ID.

1.2 Register the Downstream API

  1. Register a second app for your downstream API:
    • Add an Application (Client) ID for the API (e.g., MyAPI).
  2. Define an Application ID URI under Expose an API:
    • Example: api://<YOUR-API-CLIENT-ID>.
  3. Add a scope:
    • Scope Name: access_as_user.
    • Admin Consent Display Name: Access My API as the signed-in user.
  4. Grant permissions:
    • Go to API Permissions.
    • Add the scope access_as_user.

2. Configure the Blazor Server App

2.1 Install Required Packages

Install the required NuGet packages:

dotnet add package Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect

dotnet add package Microsoft.Identity.Web

dotnet add package Microsoft.Identity.Web.UI

2.2 Configure Authentication in Program.cs

Update your Program.cs to use Azure AD authentication and set up token acquisition for the downstream API:

using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect;

using Microsoft.Identity.Web;

using Microsoft.Identity.Web.UI;

 

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

 

// Add Authentication and Azure AD configuration

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"))

    .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()

    .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();

 

// Configure HTTP Client for Downstream API

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("DownstreamAPI", client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com/");

}).AddMicrosoftIdentityUserAccessTokenHandler();

 

// Add Razor Pages and Blazor Services

builder.Services.AddRazorPages();

builder.Services.AddServerSideBlazor()

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityConsentHandler();

 

var app = builder.Build();

 

// Middleware Pipeline

if (!app.Environment.IsDevelopment())

{

    app.UseExceptionHandler("/Error");

    app.UseHsts();

}

 

app.UseHttpsRedirection();

app.UseStaticFiles();

app.UseRouting();

 

app.UseAuthentication();

app.UseAuthorization();

 

app.MapBlazorHub();

app.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");

 

app.Run();

2.3 Configure appsettings.json

Add Azure AD and downstream API configurations in the appsettings.json file:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "<YOUR-DOMAIN>.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "<YOUR-TENANT-ID>",

    "ClientId": "<YOUR-CLIENT-ID>",

    "ClientSecret": "<YOUR-CLIENT-SECRET>",

    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"

  },

  "DownstreamApi": {

    "BaseUrl": "https://api.example.com/",

    "Scopes": "api://<YOUR-API-CLIENT-ID>/access_as_user"

  }

}

Replace <YOUR-DOMAIN>, <YOUR-TENANT-ID>, <YOUR-CLIENT-ID>, and <YOUR-API-CLIENT-ID> with your Azure AD app details.

2.4 Protect Pages and Components

Update the App.razor to enforce authentication:

<CascadingAuthenticationState>

    <Router AppAssembly="@typeof(App).Assembly">

        <Found Context="routeData">

            <AuthorizeRouteView RouteData="@routeData" DefaultLayout="@typeof(MainLayout)" />

        </Found>

        <NotFound>

            <LayoutView Layout="@typeof(MainLayout)">

                <p>Sorry, there's nothing at this address.</p>

            </LayoutView>

        </NotFound>

    </Router>

</CascadingAuthenticationState>

3. Call Downstream API

Inject the HttpClient configured for the downstream API and use it to make authenticated requests.

Inject and Use HttpClient

@inject IHttpClientFactory HttpClientFactory

 

<h3>Data from Downstream API</h3>

 

@if (data == null)

{

    <p>Loading...</p>

}

else

{

    <p>Data: @data</p>

}

 

@code {

    private string? data;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        var client = HttpClientFactory.CreateClient("DownstreamAPI");

        data = await client.GetStringAsync("endpoint");

    }

}

4. Add Role-Based Authorization (Optional)

4.1 Configure Azure AD Roles

  1. In Azure AD, define App Roles under the App Registration:
    • Add roles like Admin or User.
    • Assign these roles to users.

4.2 Enforce Authorization in Pages

Use the [Authorize] attribute with roles to restrict access:

Authorize Attribute Example

@attribute [Authorize(Roles = "Admin")]

 

<h3>Admin Page</h3>

<p>Only users with the Admin role can see this page.</p>

Display Based on Role

<AuthorizeView Roles="Admin">

    <Authorized>

        <p>Welcome, Admin!</p>

    </Authorized>

    <NotAuthorized>

        <p>You are not authorized to view this content.</p>

    </NotAuthorized>

</AuthorizeView>

5. Test the Application

  1. Run the app.
  2. Navigate to a protected page or make a downstream API call.
  3. Log in via Azure AD.
  4. Verify that:
    • The app redirects to Azure AD for authentication.
    • Pages enforce proper authorization based on roles.
    • Downstream API calls include access tokens in the Authorization header.

Summary

This setup ensures:

  • Authentication: Uses Azure AD to authenticate users.
  • Authorization: Protects pages and components based on roles.
  • Downstream API: Calls APIs securely with tokens.

 

 

Q: Blazor server app: Exception :OpenIdConnectAuthenticationHandler: message.State is null or empty

 

Ans:

The exception OpenIdConnectAuthenticationHandler: message.State is null or empty typically occurs in Blazor Server applications when the state parameter in the OpenID Connect authentication flow is not properly preserved between the initial request to the identity provider (Azure AD) and the callback to the application.

This issue often arises due to one of the following reasons:

1. Missing or Misconfigured Data Protection

Blazor Server apps use data protection to encrypt and decrypt the state parameter in the authentication process. If data protection is not correctly configured (especially in load-balanced or distributed environments), this error may occur.

Solution: Configure Data Protection

In a load-balanced environment, configure a shared key storage for data protection.

builder.Services.AddDataProtection()

    .PersistKeysToFileSystem(new DirectoryInfo(@"C:\keys"))

    .SetApplicationName("BlazorServerApp");

Replace C:\keys with a shared location accessible to all instances of the application.

2. Misconfigured Redirect URI

If the redirect URI in the Azure AD app registration does not match the actual URI used by the application, the state parameter might not be preserved correctly.

Solution: Verify Redirect URI

  1. Go to Azure Portal > App Registrations > Your App > Authentication.
  2. Ensure the Redirect URI is correct:
    • For development: https://localhost:5001/signin-oidc
    • For production: Use the actual production URL followed by /signin-oidc.

3. HTTPS Requirement

Azure AD requires HTTPS for OpenID Connect redirections. Using HTTP in development without proper configuration can lead to this error.

Solution: Use HTTPS

Ensure your application is running on HTTPS. For local development:

  • Use https://localhost:5001 (default for ASP.NET Core).
  • If needed, generate a development certificate and trust it.

4. Incorrect Middleware Order

The middleware pipeline in Program.cs must be correctly configured to handle authentication and authorization.

Solution: Verify Middleware Order

Ensure the UseAuthentication and UseAuthorization middleware are in the correct order:

app.UseAuthentication();

app.UseAuthorization();

This must appear before mapping endpoints, like MapBlazorHub and MapFallbackToPage.

5. Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Issues

The state parameter acts as an anti-CSRF token. If cookies are blocked or tampered with, the parameter may not be sent back correctly.

Solution: Check Browser Settings

  • Ensure cookies are not being blocked.
  • Avoid running the app in incognito mode without allowing cookies.

6. Session State or Load Balancing Issues

In Blazor Server, session-related issues in distributed environments can cause the state to be lost.

Solution: Sticky Sessions

If using a load balancer, enable sticky sessions to ensure the user's requests are consistently routed to the same server instance.

7. Debugging Steps

If the above solutions don't resolve the issue, try the following:

  1. Enable Detailed Logging: Add logging to get more context on the error.
  2. builder.Logging.SetMinimumLevel(LogLevel.Debug);
  3. Inspect Network Traffic: Use browser developer tools or a network monitoring tool like Fiddler to verify that:
    • The state parameter is sent with the initial request to Azure AD.
    • The same state is returned in the callback.
  4. Check Token Cache: Ensure the token cache is configured correctly if you're using EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi.

Example Configuration in Program.cs

Here's a typical configuration for Azure AD in a Blazor Server app:

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

 

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"))

    .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()

    .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();

 

builder.Services.AddRazorPages();

builder.Services.AddServerSideBlazor()

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityConsentHandler();

 

builder.Services.AddDataProtection()

    .PersistKeysToFileSystem(new DirectoryInfo(@"C:\keys"))

    .SetApplicationName("BlazorServerApp");

 

var app = builder.Build();

 

app.UseHttpsRedirection();

app.UseStaticFiles();

app.UseRouting();

 

app.UseAuthentication();

app.UseAuthorization();

 

app.MapBlazorHub();

app.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");

 

app.Run();

Summary

If you're still experiencing issues, confirm the following:

  1. Redirect URIs match between Azure AD and your application.
  2. Data protection is configured, especially for distributed environments.
  3. HTTPS is used correctly.
  4. Middleware order is correct in Program.cs.
  5. Sticky sessions are enabled if you're using load balancing.

These steps should resolve the message.State is null or empty issue in your Blazor Server app.

 

Q: where do i see messgae.state

 

Ans:

The message.State value is part of the OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol. It is not directly visible in your application code, but you can observe and debug it in the following ways:

1. Use Debug Logging

Enable detailed logging in your Blazor Server application to capture the OpenID Connect authentication flow and see information about the message.State.

Update Logging Configuration in Program.cs:

builder.Logging.ClearProviders();

builder.Logging.AddConsole();

builder.Logging.AddDebug();

builder.Logging.SetMinimumLevel(LogLevel.Debug);

This will output detailed authentication and OIDC logs to the console or log files, depending on your setup.

Look for entries from OpenIdConnectAuthenticationHandler in the logs. These will provide insights into the authentication process, including the state parameter.

2. Inspect Network Traffic

The state parameter is passed as part of the URL query string during the OIDC authentication process. You can view it using browser developer tools or a network monitoring tool.

Steps in Browser Developer Tools:

  1. Open your browser (e.g., Chrome or Edge) and navigate to the Blazor app.
  2. Trigger a login to Azure AD.
  3. Open the Developer Tools (F12) > Go to the Network tab.
  4. Filter for requests to your Azure AD tenant's login endpoint (https://login.microsoftonline.com/).
  5. Inspect the query string parameters in the URL. Look for state.

Example:

https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant-id}/oauth2/v2.0/authorize?

client_id={client-id}&

response_type=code&

state={state-value}&

...

  1. After authentication, check the callback URL to your app (e.g., /signin-oidc). The state value should also be present in the query string of this request.

3. Use a Network Monitoring Tool

If you need a more detailed view of the requests and responses, use a network monitoring tool like Fiddler or Postman Interceptor.

With Fiddler:

  1. Install and start Fiddler.
  2. Run your application and start the authentication process.
  3. Look for the HTTP requests to Azure AD and the corresponding callback to your app.
  4. Inspect the state parameter in both the outgoing and incoming requests.

4. Capture Middleware Exceptions

If the message.State is null or empty due to a middleware issue, you can catch the exception and log additional details.

Custom Middleware Example:

app.Use(async (context, next) =>

{

    try

    {

        await next.Invoke();

    }

    catch (Exception ex)

    {

        if (ex.Message.Contains("message.State is null or empty"))

        {

            Console.WriteLine("State parameter issue detected.");

            // Log more details, e.g., request context

            Console.WriteLine($"Request Path: {context.Request.Path}");

            Console.WriteLine($"Query String: {context.Request.QueryString}");

        }

        throw;

    }

});

Why message.State Matters

The state parameter is used in OIDC to:

  1. Prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF):
    • The application sends a randomly generated state value to Azure AD.
    • Azure AD returns the same state to the app, ensuring the request originates from the app.
  2. Maintain Application Context:
    • The state can contain information like where to redirect the user after authentication.

Common Causes for message.State Issues

  • Misconfigured Redirect URI: Azure AD callback doesn’t match the application URI.
  • Cookies Disabled: The state parameter relies on cookies for maintaining the user's session.
  • Distributed Environment Issues: State is lost between servers without proper data protection or session management.

By inspecting the state parameter in logs or network tools, you can identify and debug the root cause of the issue.

 

Q: signin-oidc is mandatory

 

Ans:

Yes, the /signin-oidc endpoint is mandatory in most cases when using OpenID Connect (OIDC) with Azure AD in an ASP.NET Core or Blazor Server app. This is because it serves as the default redirect URI for handling the authentication response from Azure AD.

Why /signin-oidc Is Important

  1. OIDC Protocol Requirement:
    • During the OIDC authentication flow, Azure AD sends the authentication response (tokens, state, etc.) back to the app via a predefined redirect URI.
    • The app must have a designated endpoint to process this response and finalize the authentication handshake.
  2. Default Configuration in Middleware:
    • The Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.OpenIdConnect middleware expects /signin-oidc by default.
    • This endpoint listens for the authentication callback from Azure AD.
  3. Security:
    • Redirect URIs are validated by Azure AD to prevent attacks. Azure AD ensures the response goes to the correct application by requiring a pre-registered redirect URI.

Can You Customize the Redirect URI?

Yes, you can customize the redirect URI if /signin-oidc doesn’t suit your needs.

Steps to Customize Redirect URI:

  1. Update Azure AD App Registration:
    • Go to Azure Portal > App Registrations > Your App > Authentication.
    • Add a new redirect URI, e.g., https://localhost:5001/custom-oidc-callback.
  2. Update Your App's Configuration: In appsettings.json, specify the custom redirect URI:
  3. {
  4.   "AzureAd": {
  5.     "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",
  6.     "Domain": "<YOUR-DOMAIN>.onmicrosoft.com",
  7.     "TenantId": "<YOUR-TENANT-ID>",
  8.     "ClientId": "<YOUR-CLIENT-ID>",
  9.     "CallbackPath": "/custom-oidc-callback"
  10.      }
  11.    }
  12. Update the Middleware: The CallbackPath in the Microsoft.Identity.Web or OpenIdConnect middleware must match the custom path:
  13.    builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
  14.        .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"));

Key Considerations

  • If you customize the redirect URI, ensure it is unique and clearly defined in both Azure AD and the application configuration.
  • In multi-environment setups (e.g., development, staging, production), each environment may need its own redirect URI (e.g., https://staging.myapp.com/signin-oidc).

Summary

  • By default, /signin-oidc is mandatory as the default callback endpoint for OIDC in Blazor Server apps.
  • You can customize it by changing the CallbackPath in your app and updating Azure AD to reflect this change.
  • Always ensure the app and Azure AD configurations match to avoid issues like invalid_redirect_uri errors.

 

Q: Downstream api in azure AD

 

Ans:

In the context of Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), a downstream API refers to an API that your application (a client) calls on behalf of a user or another application using an access token issued by Azure AD.

Key Concepts of Downstream APIs in Azure AD

  1. Access Token:
    • When a user or app signs in, Azure AD issues an access token.
    • This token contains claims and permissions (scopes) that the downstream API validates to authorize the caller.
  2. Protected Resources:
    • A downstream API is typically a protected resource that requires authorization to access, such as Microsoft Graph, custom APIs, or third-party APIs.
  3. Delegated Permissions vs. Application Permissions:
    • Delegated Permissions: The API is accessed on behalf of a signed-in user (user's identity and consent).
    • Application Permissions: The API is accessed as the app itself without a user (e.g., background services).
  4. Scopes (API Permissions):
    • Downstream APIs define permissions (scopes) in their Azure AD app registration.
    • Example: Microsoft Graph exposes scopes like User.Read, Mail.Read.
  5. Authorization Flow:
    • Azure AD ensures the caller has the necessary permissions and issues an access token for the downstream API.

Scenario: Calling a Downstream API from a Blazor App

For example, consider a Blazor Server app that needs to:

  1. Authenticate users via Azure AD.
  2. Call Microsoft Graph API (downstream API) to fetch user profile details.

Steps to Set Up and Use a Downstream API

1. Register the Downstream API in Azure AD

If you're using your own API:

  1. Go to Azure Portal > App Registrations > New Registration.
  2. Register your API and note its Application (Client) ID.
  3. Define API permissions (scopes) under Expose an API, such as:
    • api://{client-id}/read
    • api://{client-id}/write

If you're using a predefined API like Microsoft Graph, you can skip this step.

2. Register the Client App in Azure AD

  1. Go to Azure Portal > App Registrations > New Registration.
  2. Register your Blazor Server app and configure its redirect URI (e.g., /signin-oidc).
  3. Under API Permissions, add:
    • Microsoft Graph permissions (e.g., User.Read).
    • Your custom downstream API scopes (e.g., api://{client-id}/read).

3. Enable Token Acquisition

Add support for token acquisition in your Blazor Server app using Microsoft.Identity.Web.

Configure appsettings.json:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "yourdomain.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "your-tenant-id",

    "ClientId": "your-client-id",

    "ClientSecret": "your-client-secret",

    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"

  },

  "DownstreamApi": {

    "BaseUrl": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/",

    "Scopes": "User.Read"

  }

}

Configure Services in Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"))

    .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()

    .AddDownstreamWebApi("DownstreamApi", builder.Configuration.GetSection("DownstreamApi"))

    .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();

4. Call the Downstream API

Use the IDownstreamWebApi service to call the downstream API with the appropriate access token.

Example in a Razor Component:

@inject IDownstreamWebApi DownstreamWebApi

@code {

    private string userProfile;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        try

        {

            userProfile = await DownstreamWebApi.CallWebApiForUserAsync<string>("DownstreamApi", options =>

            {

                options.RelativePath = "me";

            });

        }

        catch (Exception ex)

        {

            userProfile = $"Error: {ex.Message}";

        }

    }

}

Authorization for Pages and Components

To apply authorization to Blazor pages or components:

  1. Use the [Authorize] attribute:
  2. @attribute [Authorize]
  3. To restrict access based on roles or policies:
  4. @attribute [Authorize(Roles = "Admin")]
  5. @attribute [Authorize(Policy = "YourPolicyName")]

Summary

  • Downstream API: A protected API (e.g., Microsoft Graph or your own) accessed by the Blazor app.
  • Azure AD: Issues access tokens with appropriate permissions for calling downstream APIs.
  • Blazor Server: Use Microsoft.Identity.Web to acquire tokens and integrate them into API requests.

This setup ensures secure communication between your Blazor app and any downstream API.

 

Q:  https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/ everyone can use this or to set any downstreamapi

 

Ans:

The Microsoft Graph API (https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/) is a protected resource, meaning not everyone can access it directly. To use it in your application, you must meet specific requirements:

Access Requirements for Microsoft Graph

  1. Azure AD App Registration:
    • You must register your application in Azure Active Directory.
    • The app registration defines what permissions your app needs to access Microsoft Graph.
  2. API Permissions:
    • Assign the required API permissions (e.g., User.Read, Mail.Read, Directory.Read.All) to your Azure AD app registration.
    • Permissions can be:
      • Delegated Permissions (access on behalf of a signed-in user).
      • Application Permissions (access as the application itself, without a user).
  3. Admin Consent:
    • Some permissions require admin approval in Azure AD, such as Directory.Read.All or Mail.Send.
    • Admins can grant consent to permissions in the Azure portal.
  4. Access Tokens:
    • Your app must authenticate with Azure AD to obtain an access token.
    • This access token must include the required scopes (permissions) to call specific Graph endpoints.

How to Use Microsoft Graph as a Downstream API

If you want to use Microsoft Graph in your application as a downstream API, follow these steps:

1. Register Your Application in Azure AD

  • Go to Azure Portal > App Registrations > New Registration.
  • Specify the redirect URI (e.g., /signin-oidc).

2. Assign API Permissions

  • Under the API Permissions tab in the app registration, click Add a Permission.
  • Select Microsoft Graph > Choose the required permissions.
    • Examples:
      • User.Read (Delegated) – To read the profile of the signed-in user.
      • Mail.Read (Delegated) – To read the user's emails.
      • Directory.Read.All (Application) – To read directory data (requires admin consent).

3. Configure Your App to Acquire Tokens

  • Use the Microsoft.Identity.Web library to integrate Azure AD authentication and token acquisition.

Example Configuration:

In appsettings.json:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "yourtenant.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "your-tenant-id",

    "ClientId": "your-client-id",

    "ClientSecret": "your-client-secret",

    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"

  },

  "DownstreamApi": {

    "BaseUrl": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/",

    "Scopes": "User.Read"

  }

}

In Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(OpenIdConnectDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)

    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApp(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"))

    .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()

    .AddDownstreamWebApi("GraphApi", builder.Configuration.GetSection("DownstreamApi"))

    .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();

4. Call Microsoft Graph

Use IDownstreamWebApi to make authenticated calls to Graph.

@inject IDownstreamWebApi DownstreamWebApi

@code {

    private string userName;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        try

        {

            var profile = await DownstreamWebApi.CallWebApiForUserAsync<dynamic>("GraphApi", options =>

            {

                options.RelativePath = "me";

            });

            userName = profile.displayName;

        }

        catch (Exception ex)

        {

            userName = $"Error: {ex.Message}";

        }

    }

}

Custom Downstream API

If you want to use a custom API instead of Microsoft Graph:

  1. Register Your API in Azure AD:
    • Go to App Registrations > Register your API.
    • Under Expose an API, define scopes like api://{client-id}/read.
  2. Authorize Clients:
    • Allow client applications to request tokens for your API.
  3. Update Client App Configuration:
    • Add your API's scopes to the API Permissions section of the client app registration.
    • Update the DownstreamApi configuration in the Blazor app.
  4. Protect Your API:
    • Use Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer in your API to validate Azure AD tokens.

Summary

  • Microsoft Graph API is protected and requires proper app registration, permissions, and access tokens for usage.
  • You can integrate it into your Blazor app as a downstream API using Azure AD and Microsoft.Identity.Web.
  • For custom APIs, follow a similar flow: register the API in Azure AD, expose scopes, and acquire tokens to authenticate.

 

Q: clientsecret value is mandatory for blazor app to connect azure AD

 

Ans:

The client secret is not always mandatory for a Blazor app to connect to Azure AD. Whether you need it depends on the type of authentication flow your app is using:

When Client Secret is Not Required

  1. Blazor Server Apps (Interactive Authentication):
    • In Blazor Server, users authenticate interactively through the Authorization Code Flow.
    • In this flow, the app acts as a confidential client, but since it's not a daemon or background service, a client secret is not strictly required.
    • Azure AD can authenticate the app and issue tokens based on the client ID and user consent.

Example Configuration Without Client Secret:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "yourdomain.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "your-tenant-id",

    "ClientId": "your-client-id",

    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"

  }

}

  1. Public Client Applications:
    • For apps like Blazor WebAssembly (running in the browser), no client secret is used because it would expose the secret to the client. Instead:
      • Only the client ID is required.
      • Blazor WebAssembly apps use the PKCE (Proof Key for Code Exchange) extension to secure the token exchange.

When Client Secret is Required

  1. Blazor Server Apps Calling Downstream APIs:
    • If your Blazor Server app calls downstream APIs (e.g., Microsoft Graph), it acts as a confidential client.
    • In this case, a client secret (or certificate) is required to securely authenticate the app to Azure AD when acquiring tokens.

Example Scenario:

  • Your app fetches an access token for a downstream API (e.g., User.Read for Microsoft Graph).

Configuration:

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "yourdomain.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "your-tenant-id",

    "ClientId": "your-client-id",

    "ClientSecret": "your-client-secret",

    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"

  }

}

  1. Daemon Apps (Non-Interactive):
    • For background services or APIs with no user interaction, the app must authenticate as itself using a client secret or certificate.

Alternative to Client Secrets: Certificates

For greater security, you can use a certificate instead of a client secret. Certificates are more secure for production environments because:

  • Client secrets can be compromised if exposed in configuration files.
  • Certificates can be rotated automatically and securely stored in services like Azure Key Vault.

Configuration for Certificates: Replace ClientSecret with a certificate configuration in your app.

{

  "AzureAd": {

    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",

    "Domain": "yourdomain.onmicrosoft.com",

    "TenantId": "your-tenant-id",

    "ClientId": "your-client-id",

    "ClientCertificates": ["path/to/your/certificate.pfx"]

  }

}

Summary

  • Client Secret is not mandatory for:
    • Blazor Server apps with interactive user sign-in.
    • Blazor WebAssembly apps (they use PKCE and avoid secrets for security).
  • Client Secret is required for:
    • Server-side apps calling downstream APIs.
    • Non-interactive daemon apps.
  • Consider using certificates for enhanced security in production.

 

Q: register the httpclient in program.cs

 

Ans:

To register an HttpClient in Program.cs for dependency injection in a Blazor application (either Server or WebAssembly), you can use the AddHttpClient method provided by .NET. Here's how you can do it:

1. Register HttpClient in Blazor Server App

In Blazor Server, the HttpClient is used for making HTTP calls to external APIs or services.

Example Code:

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

 

// Add services to the container.

builder.Services.AddRazorPages();

builder.Services.AddServerSideBlazor();

 

// Register HttpClient with a base address

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("MyApiClient", client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com/");

});

 

// Optionally, register a named HttpClient for direct injection

builder.Services.AddHttpClient<IMyApiService, MyApiService>(client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com/");

});

 

var app = builder.Build();

 

// Configure the HTTP request pipeline.

if (!app.Environment.IsDevelopment())

{

    app.UseExceptionHandler("/Error");

    app.UseHsts();

}

 

app.UseHttpsRedirection();

app.UseStaticFiles();

app.UseRouting();

app.MapBlazorHub();

app.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");

 

app.Run();

Usage in a Component:

@inject IHttpClientFactory HttpClientFactory

 

@code {

    private string data;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        var httpClient = HttpClientFactory.CreateClient("MyApiClient");

        data = await httpClient.GetStringAsync("endpoint");

    }

}

2. Register HttpClient in Blazor WebAssembly App

In Blazor WebAssembly, the HttpClient is already preconfigured to make requests to the same server hosting the app. However, you can customize it to point to external APIs.

Example Code:

In Program.cs:

var builder = WebAssemblyHostBuilder.CreateDefault(args);

builder.RootComponents.Add<App>("#app");

 

// Register HttpClient with a base address

builder.Services.AddHttpClient("MyApiClient", client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com/");

});

 

// Optional: Register an interface-based service for HttpClient

builder.Services.AddScoped<IMyApiService, MyApiService>();

 

await builder.Build().RunAsync();

Usage in a Component:

@inject IHttpClientFactory HttpClientFactory

 

@code {

    private string data;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        var httpClient = HttpClientFactory.CreateClient("MyApiClient");

        data = await httpClient.GetStringAsync("endpoint");

    }

}

Custom Service with HttpClient

For a cleaner approach, you can wrap HttpClient in a custom service.

Example Service:

public interface IMyApiService

{

    Task<string> GetDataAsync(string endpoint);

}

 

public class MyApiService : IMyApiService

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

 

    public MyApiService(HttpClient httpClient)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

    }

 

    public async Task<string> GetDataAsync(string endpoint)

    {

        return await _httpClient.GetStringAsync(endpoint);

    }

}

Registration in Program.cs:

builder.Services.AddHttpClient<IMyApiService, MyApiService>(client =>

{

    client.BaseAddress = new Uri("https://api.example.com/");

});

Usage in a Component:

@inject IMyApiService MyApiService

 

@code {

    private string data;

 

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()

    {

        data = await MyApiService.GetDataAsync("endpoint");

    }

}

Summary

  • Use AddHttpClient to register HttpClient with a base address.
  • Use named or typed clients for modularity.
  • Wrap HttpClient in custom services for cleaner code and reusability.

 

Q: implementation of IMyApiService, MyApiService

 

Ans:

Here’s how you can implement the IMyApiService interface and MyApiService class to manage API calls in a Blazor application:

Interface Definition (IMyApiService)

Define the contract for your service with methods that represent the API operations:

public interface IMyApiService

{

    Task<string> GetDataAsync(string endpoint);

    Task<T> GetDataAsync<T>(string endpoint);

    Task<bool> PostDataAsync<T>(string endpoint, T data);

    Task<bool> PutDataAsync<T>(string endpoint, T data);

    Task<bool> DeleteDataAsync(string endpoint);

}

Service Implementation (MyApiService)

Implement the IMyApiService interface using HttpClient to perform API calls.

using System.Net.Http;

using System.Text;

using System.Text.Json;

using System.Threading.Tasks;

 

public class MyApiService : IMyApiService

{

    private readonly HttpClient _httpClient;

 

    public MyApiService(HttpClient httpClient)

    {

        _httpClient = httpClient;

    }

 

    public async Task<string> GetDataAsync(string endpoint)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(endpoint);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        return await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync();

    }

 

    public async Task<T> GetDataAsync<T>(string endpoint)

    {

        var response = await _httpClient.GetAsync(endpoint);

        response.EnsureSuccessStatusCode();

        var jsonString = await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync();

        return JsonSerializer.Deserialize<T>(jsonString, new JsonSerializerOptions { PropertyNameCaseInsensitive = true });

    }

 

    public async Task<bool> PostDataAsync<T>(string endpoint, T data)

    {

        var jsonContent = new StringContent(JsonSerializer.Serialize(data), Encoding.UTF8, "application/json");

        var response = await _httpClient.PostAsync(endpoint, jsonContent);

        return response.IsSuccessStatusCode;

    }

 

    public async Task<bool> PutDataAsync<T>(string endpoint, T data)

    {
